text: Is anyone else quite worried about the potential impact that this review might have on the exchange model? Social media is a cesspit for sure, but I have seen talk from people who "work in the industry" of monthly loss limits and means tested deposit limits. I don't want to see people having problems from gambling, but there must be better ways to deal with that than blanket limits and restrictions.

elements.text: Is anyone else quite worried about the potential impact that this review might have on the exchange model? text: I'm looking for suggestions for historical horse ratings on websites which could be scraped (I already have RPR and TS from <http://racingpost.com|racingpost.com>). Timeform is an obvious one but I suspect it is exorbitantly expensive to get full access.

text: Yeah I’m worried, less so about the probability of a bad outcome and more so about the size of the impact it could have. Obviously I’m comfortable with the variance in betting profits so the thing that keeps me up at night are the existential threats.

elements.text: Yeah I’m worried, less so about the probability of a bad outcome and more so about the size of the impact it could have. Obviously I’m comfortable with the variance in betting profits so the thing that keeps me up at night are the existential threats.

text: Totally agree. I think the exchange model would be trashed completely if loss limits were forced on users and that would be game over for me. It does make me angry that such things are even discussed as an option - can you imagine the uproar if people were only allowed to consume 5 units of alcohol per week or 10 cigarettes per week. I can piss my life savings up a wall and nobody is concerned but if I want to gamble with the same money its a problem. Really hope common sense prevails, but given recent events I have very little faith in decision makers right now.

elements.text: Totally agree. I think the exchange model would be trashed completely if loss limits were forced on users and that would be game over for me. It does make me angry that such things are even discussed as an option - can you imagine the uproar if people were only allowed to consume 5 units of alcohol per week or 10 cigarettes per week. I can piss my life savings up a wall and nobody is concerned but if I want to gamble with the same money its a problem. Really hope common sense prevails, but given recent events I have very little faith in decision makers right now.

text: I was going to make the same argument; we are obviously biased but the invasiveness of controlling what people spend their money on for entertainment is disgusting

elements.text: I was going to make the same argument; we are obviously biased but the invasiveness of controlling what people spend their money on for entertainment is disgusting

text:
Yeah, I’m surprised people aren’t talking about it more. I only found out about the survey because my account manager sent me the link. 

I try not to think about existential threats too much. We can only control so much. I’m trying to accept that if it’s over then it’s over. Sports betting has started to feel too much like “a job” and chore for me the last couple years. Having said all that, I still find it hard to properly move onto something else. So maybe I AM addicted! :joy:

elements.text: Yeah, I’m surprised people aren’t talking about it more. I only found out about the survey because my account manager sent me the link.

text: Yeah, I didn’t actually write very much myself. I’m hoping others will be more eloquent than me which is why I posted it :grimacing::joy:. But also just having more voices from our sort of community can’t hurt.

elements.text: Yeah, I didn’t actually write very much myself. I’m hoping others will be more eloquent than me which is why I posted it
. But also just having more voices from our sort of community can’t hurt.

text: At the end of the day, if people are genuinely addicted to gambling they will find a way to do it. Be it some dodgy bitcoin casino or worse. Encouraging people to seek help and getting bookies to flag problem accounts and act on it has to be better. After all, they already KNOW about most of these problem accounts but are clearly allowed to get away with doing nothing about it (other than target them with free bet offers and other stuff that fuels addiction).

elements.text: At the end of the day, if people are genuinely addicted to gambling they will find a way to do it. Be it some dodgy bitcoin casino or worse. Encouraging people to seek help and getting bookies to flag problem accounts and act on it has to be better. After all, they already KNOW about most of these problem accounts but are clearly allowed to get away with doing nothing about it (other than target them with free bet offers and other stuff that fuels addiction).

text: Yeah, that’s talked about a bit in the “unintended consequences” section - that people might just move to black markets for example. I think anything related to addictions is a tricky problem to solve.

elements.text: Yeah, that’s talked about a bit in the “unintended consequences” section - that people might just move to black markets for example. I think anything related to addictions is a tricky problem to solve.

text: Fucking hell that was boring to complete

elements.text: Fucking hell that was boring to complete

text: :joy: You did it for our greater good, Mo.

elements.text: You did it for our greater good, Mo.

text:
My hope is they take the easy win of replicating the stake limits on betting shop FOBTs to the online casino games and leave sports/racing wagering alone.

The monthly loss limits that are being rumoured can be bypassed with affordability checks which prove you can afford to lose more but god knows how they will actually implement those, particularly for people who are doing this full time.

Another unintended consequence would be the damage it would do to the racing industry with a drop in betting turnover leading to less levy income being filtered back in.

elements.text:
My hope is they take the easy win of replicating the stake limits on betting shop FOBTs to the online casino games and leave sports/racing wagering alone.

The monthly loss limits that are being rumoured can be bypassed with affordability checks which prove you can afford to lose more but god knows how they will actually implement those, particularly for people who are doing this full time.

Another unintended consequence would be the damage it would do to the racing industry with a drop in betting turnover leading to less levy income being filtered back in.

text: I agree. Online slots could be forced to have their "fast" spin modes removed so you can't spank hundreds of quid in seconds. That combined with stake reductions and maybe enforced time delays on new deposits to stop people chasing losses. I don't know, but you would hope that they would see the difference between sports betting and casino/games.

elements.text: I agree. Online slots could be forced to have their "fast" spin modes removed so you can't spank hundreds of quid in seconds. text: You just feel that bookies know full well who the problem gamblers are but are currently allowed to pretend that they don't and let it slide. Ultimately though, only a problem gambler themself can make that decision to seek help.

text: One potential thing to be aware of for modelling with RPRs is they are not set in stone and are sometimes adjusted retrospectively. This is not a frequent thing but is enough to be a potential source of data leakage and throw off a model in production

elements.text: One potential thing to be aware of for modelling with RPRs is they are not set in stone and are sometimes adjusted retrospectively. This is not a frequent thing but is enough to be a potential source of data leakage and throw off a model in production

text:
I'm sure this has been asked before, but I couldn't see anything in the search...

Does  `order.elapsed_seconds` start when an order is placed in Flumine, or when an order is executable (in short I'm just trying to clarify whether when order.elapsed = 1 for in-play does that mean the order has been placed, post delay and has been live for 1 second, or does that mean it has been pending and is now turning active)?

elements.text:
I'm sure this has been asked before, but I couldn't see anything in the search...

Does
order.elapsed_seconds

start when an order is placed in Flumine, or when an order is executable (in short I'm just trying to clarify whether when order.elapsed = 1 for in-play does that mean the order has been placed, post delay and has been live for 1 second, or does that mean it has been pending and is now turning active)?

text: <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/2adcd24379e07dfc1a017ffcc7895d99102814ee/flumine/order/order.py#L223|https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/2adcd24379e07dfc1a017ffcc7895d99102814ee/flumine/order/order.py#L223>

elements.text: https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/2adcd24379e07dfc1a017ffcc7895d99102814ee/flumine/order/order.py#L223

text: date_time_placed is once a response has been received from betfair so once the order is executable

text: <@UUCD6P13J> there is a great thread on this on the Betangel forum <https://forum.betangel.com/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=20578&hilit=invest> Id say that paying off any debts you may have (ie mortgage)  and have at least 6 months easy access cash are the first things. I dont know if this is the best advice but its an immensely powerful feeling knowing you dont owe anyone a penny. Then invest any excess thereafter. More on the above thread. PS Hope Betfair is starting to pay its way for you :+1: PSS Wish Id bought some bitcoin in 2013 when I initially thought of doing so :cry:
